[[World War I]] |awards= |laterwork= }} '''John W. Heavey''' (February 19, 1867 – November 18, 1941) was a [[United States Army]] [[Brigadier General (United States)|Brigadier General]] who served as [[Chief of the National Guard Bureau]]. ==Early life== John William Heavey was born in [[Vandalia, Illinois]] on February 19, 1867 and graduated from Vandalia High School in 1884.Henry Blaine Davis, [https://books.google.com/books?id=fJvvAAAAMAAJ&q=john+william+heavey+vandalia&dq=john+william+heavey+vandalia&hl=en&sa=X&ei=tmuGUfHeMrD_4APut4G4Bw&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAg ''Generals in Khaki''], 1998, page 170 He graduated from the [[United States Military Academy]] in 1891, receiving his commission as a [[Second lieutenant#United States|Second Lieutenant]] of [[Infantry Branch (United States)|Infantry]]. Heavey served with the [[5th Infantry Regiment (United States)|5th Infantry Regiment]] in several southern states and [[New York (state)|New York]] between 1891 and 1898.George Washington Cullum, [https://books.google.com/books?id=nSe5AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA590&dq=%22john+w+heavey%22+west+point+1891&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nmyGUcaaD9ey4AOI6oHQCw&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22john%20w%20heavey%22%20west%20point%201891&f=false ''Biographical Register of the Officers and Graduates of the United States Military Academy''], Volume 6, Part 1, 1920, pages 590–591 A member of one of West Point's earliest football teams, Heavey was the right [[Guard (American and Canadian football)|guard]] on Army's [[American football positions#Offensive line|offensive line]] during the first [[Army-Navy Game]] in 1890.West Point Association of Graduates, [http://apps.westpointaog.org/Memorials/Article/3417/ Biography, John W. Heavey 1891], accessed May 5, 2013 ==Spanish–American War== In 1898 Heavey joined the [[11th Infantry Regiment (United States)|11th Infantry]] for the [[Spanish–American War]], serving in [[Puerto Rico]], including battles at [[Hormigueros, Puerto Rico|Hormigueros]] and [[Las Marías, Puerto Rico|Las Marias]] and assignment as commander of the post at [[Mayagüez, Puerto Rico|Mayaguez]]. He remained on duty in Puerto Rico until 1902, when he was assigned to the [[Philippines]], including a posting to [[Camp Jossman]] and action against the [[Moro people|Moros]] on [[Mindanao]] and [[Jolo]].George Washington Cullum, Edward Singleton Holden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=_5neAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA519&dq=%22john+w+heavey%22+11th+infantry+puerto+rico&hl=en&sa=X&ei=L22GUZ-6KtGx4AOunYD4Dw&ved=0CD0Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22john%20w%20heavey%22%2011th%20infantry%20puerto%20rico&f=false ''Biographical Register of the Officers and Graduates of the U.S. Military Academy''], Volume IV, 1901, page 519 ==Post-Spanish–American War== In 1904 Heavey was assigned to [[Fort D.A. Russell (Wyoming)|Fort D. A. Russell]], [[Wyoming]]. He served there until 1905, when he went to the [[University of Wyoming]] as Professor of Military Science.University of Wyoming, [https://books.google.com/books?id=xpI4AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA11&dq=%22john+w+heavey%22+vandalia&hl=en&sa=X&ei=pEGFUfTgM86s0AGvwIGICA&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22john%20w%20heavey%22%20vandalia&f=false Annual Catalog], 1908, pages 11–12 In 1908 Heavey was assigned to duty in [[Cuba]] with the 11th Infantry, remaining until 1911 when he was promoted to [[Major (United States)|Major]] and carried out assignments at Fort D. A. Russell and [[Fort Sam Houston]]. Heavey graduated from the [[United States Army Command and General Staff College]] at [[Fort Leavenworth]] in 1912 and the [[United States Army War College]] in 1913.Marquis Who's Who, [https://books.google.com/books?id=rjQOAQAAMAAJ&q=%22heavey+john+william%22+cuba&dq=%22heavey+john+william%22+cuba&hl=en&sa=X&ei=O26GUefcIK7G4AOn1YCQCA&sqi=2&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA ''Who Was Who in American History: The Military''], 1975, page 248 From 1913 to 1914 Heavey was assigned as [[regular Army]] advisor to the [[Massachusetts National Guard]], and from 1914 to 1916 he was a member of the staff at the [[National Guard Bureau|Militia Bureau]].Massachusetts Adjutant General's Office, [https://books.google.com/books?id=2co8AQAAIAAJ&q=%22john+w+heavey%22+massachusetts&dq=%22john+w+heavey%22+massachusetts&hl=en&sa=X&ei=n2-GUcmCMJHC4APm9IHABA&ved=0CDEQ6AEwATgK Annual Report], 1914, page 49 In 1916 Heavey served on the Mexican border with the [[9th Infantry Regiment (United States)|9th Infantry]] during the [[Pancho Villa Expedition]]. Now a [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|Lieutenant Colonel]], he was then assigned to [[Fort Niagara]] as the commander and senior instructor for the [[Citizens' Military Training Camp|Officer Training School]]. ==World War I== During [[World War I]] Heavey received temporary promotions to [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] and Brigadier General and served as executive officer of the [[National Guard Bureau|Militia Bureau]]. From August, 1918 to February, 1919 he served as acting [[Chief of the National Guard Bureau|Chief of the Militia Bureau]] when incumbent [[Jesse McI. Carter]] was assigned to command the [[11th Infantry Division (United States)|11th Infantry Division]].George Washington Cullum, [https://books.google.com/books?id=OCe5AAAAIAAJ&q=%22john+william+heavey%22+militia+bureau&dq=%22john+william+heavey%22+militia+bureau&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YXOGUfGRCdLU0gHR7YDgCQ&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA Biographical Register of the Officers and Graduates of the U.S. Military Academy], Volume 7, 1930, page 323 Heavey’s World War I duties included responsibility for National Guard soldiers assigned to guard utilities and railroads within the United States to protect them from sabotage.Army and Navy Journal Incorporated, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Af0ZAQAAMAAJ&q=%22john+w+heavey%22+west+point+1891&dq=%22john+w+heavey%22+west+point+1891&hl=en&sa=X&ei=J2yGUaDoBfio4AOM8oH4BQ&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBQ ''Army, Navy, Air Force Journal''], Volume 89, Issues 1-26, 1951, page 424 ==Post World War I== Heavey remained as executive officer of the Militia Bureau until 1922, reverting to the permanent rank of Colonel. He was then assigned to the office of the [[Chief of Staff of the United States Army|Army Chief of Staff]]. From 1923 to 1926 he served at [[Fort Clayton]], [[Panama Canal Zone]] and successively commanded the [[20th Infantry Regiment (United States)|20th]] and [[33rd Infantry Regiment (United States)|33rd]] Infantry Regiments. From 1926 until retiring in 1931 Heavey was an Area Coordinator for the [[Office of Management and Budget|Bureau of the Budget]], assigned to [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]].West Point Association of Graduates, [https://books.google.com/books?id=xXreAAAAMAAJ&q=john+heavey+bureau+budget+philadelphia&dq=john+heavey+bureau+budget+philadelphia&hl=en&sa=X&ei=03SGUbegCanv0QGziYHgCQ&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAQ ''Register of Graduates and Former Cadets of the United States Military Academy''], 1991, page 907 ==Retirement and death== In retirement Heavey resided in [[Washington, D.C.]] where he died on November 18, 1941. He was buried at [[Arlington National Cemetery]], Section 2, Site 3513. ==Family== In 1894, Heavey married Julia Baggett (1871–1906). They had three sons: William Francis Heavey (West Point, 1917), Thomas Jackson Heavey (West Point, 1917, second class), and Wade Hampton Heavey (West Point, 1923). In 1915, Heavey married Katherine Theresa Sullivan (1868–1943). William F. Heavey (1896–1974) retired as a [[Major General (United States)|Major General]] and was the author of 1947’s ''Down Ramp! The Story of the Army Amphibian Engineers''.West Point Association of Graduates, [https://books.google.com/books?id=YzLcAAAAMAAJ&q=%22william+f.+heavey%22+74&dq=%22william+f.+heavey%22+74&hl=en&sa=X&ei=AXaGUbuBNorI0wHXkYCACw&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA ''Register of Graduates and Former Cadets of the United States Military Academy''], 1974, page 802William F. Heavey, [https://books.google.com/books?id=mpPKcQAACAAJ&dq=%22william+f.+heavey%22+down+ramp&hl=en&sa=X&ei=WnaGUd2vBeyu0AHisYC4Bg&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA ''Down Ramp! the Story of the Army Amphibian Engineers''], 1946, 2010 reprint, title page Thomas J. Heavey (1897–1951) served in the [[China Burma India Theater]] during [[World War II]] and retired as a Colonel.Historical Division, Department of the Army, [https://books.google.com/books?id=UwEdSAIvjWUC&q=%22thomas+j.+heavey%22+stilwell&dq=%22thomas+j.+heavey%22+stilwell&hl=en&sa=X&ei=t3aGUZ61BYWy0QGa0oCQDQ&ved=0CEYQ6AEwBA ''China-Burma-India Theater''], Volume 2, 1956, page xi Wade H. Heavey (1902–1961) was Assistant Comptroller of the Army and retired as a Colonel.Army and Navy Journal Incorporated, [https://books.google.com/books?id=nqkYAQAAMAAJ&q=%22wade+h.+heavey%22+comptroller&dq=%22wade+h.+heavey%22+comptroller&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IHeGUcDjKM260QGlsYHYAQ&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAQ ''Army, Navy, Air Force Journal''], Volume 98, Issues 27-52, 1961, page 1006 ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{s-bef|before=[[Jesse McI.
